definition: Perfectly clean, neat, or tidy.

examples.sentence: His white shirt was immaculate.

definition: Feeling or expressing remorse or penitence.

examples.sentence: He looked contrite after breaking the vase.

definition: To feel sincere regret or remorse about one's wrongdoing.

examples.sentence: He repented for his harsh words.

definition: Deep regret or guilt for a wrong committed.

examples.sentence: She felt no remorse for her actions.

definition: Lasting for a very short time.

examples.sentence: Fame in the digital age is often ephemeral.

definition: Perfectly clean, neat, or tidy; free from flaws or mistakes.

examples.sentence: He wore an immaculate white suit to the party.

definition: Feeling or expressing remorse or penitence; affected by guilt.

examples.sentence: She was contrite the morning after her angry outburst.

definition: To feel sincere regret or remorse about one's wrongdoing or sin.

examples.sentence: He repented of his sins before he died.

definition: Deep regret or guilt for a wrong committed.

examples.sentence: He felt no remorse for the murders he had committed.

definition: Feeling or showing sorrow and regret for having done wrong; a person who repents their sins.

examples.sentence: The penitent husband spent hours apologizing to his wife.

definition: Reparation for a wrong or injury.

examples.sentence: He wanted to find a way to make atonement for his sins.

definition: A feeling of guilt or moral scruple that follows the doing of something bad.

examples.sentence: They used their political power without compunction.

definition: To atone for (guilt or sin).

examples.sentence: He tried to expiate his crimes by giving money to the church.

definition: Not feeling shame or regret about one's actions or attitudes.

examples.sentence: He was impenitent about his criminal past.

definition: Characterized by a lack of shame; showing no shame.

examples.sentence: She is a shameless self-promoter.

definition: Irrelevant or unrelated to the subject being dealt with.

examples.sentence: We do not want any extraneous information in the report.

definition: Not connected with or relevant to something.

examples.sentence: His comment was irrelevant to the discussion.

definition: Unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.

examples.sentence: The report was marred by a mass of superfluous detail.

definition: Not or no longer needed or useful; superfluous.

examples.sentence: Many of the old skills had become redundant.

definition: Relevant or applicable to a particular matter.

examples.sentence: She asked me a lot of very pertinent questions.

definition: Relevant to a subject under consideration.

examples.sentence: That is not germane to our theme.

definition: With reference to; concerning. Very appropriate to a particular situation.

examples.sentence: The song feels apropos to the midnight setting.

definition: Apt in the circumstances or in relation to something.

examples.sentence: He added an apposite quotation to his speech; it was perfect.

definition: Equivalent in seriousness to; virtually the same as.

examples.sentence: Her silence was tantamount to an admission of guilt.

definition: Necessary to make a whole complete; essential or fundamental.

examples.sentence: Vegetables are an integral part of our diet.

definition: Absolutely necessary; extremely important.

examples.sentence: Water is essential for life.

definition: Of considerable importance, size, or worth.

examples.sentence: He made a substantial donation to the charity.

definition: Concise and exact use of words in writing or speech.

examples.sentence: The brevity of the meeting was a relief to everyone.

definition: Giving a lot of information clearly and in a few words.

examples.sentence: Make your answers clear and concise.

definition: Sparing in the use of words; abrupt.

examples.sentence: He gave a terse reply to my question.

definition: Using very few words.

examples.sentence: His laconic reply suggested a lack of interest in the topic.

definition: Containing or presenting the essential facts of something in a comprehensive but concise way.

examples.sentence: It is a compendious study of the subject.

definition: Using or containing too many words; tediously lengthy.

examples.sentence: The author's prolix style makes the book difficult to read.

definition: Using or expressed in more words than are needed.

examples.sentence: His verbose explanation confused everyone.

definition: The use of many words where fewer would do, especially in a deliberate attempt to be vague or evasive.

examples.sentence: Politicians are experts in circumlocution.

definition: A legacy; something left to someone in a will.

examples.sentence: She received a generous bequest from her aunt.

definition: A person's orders or command.

examples.sentence: They attended the meeting at the behest of the director.

definition: An official order issued by a legal authority.

examples.sentence: The President issued a decree banning public gatherings.

definition: Authoritatively or urgently call on (someone) to be present.

examples.sentence: She was summoned to the principal's office.

definition: A direction or order.

examples.sentence: Read the instructions carefully before starting.

definition: The freedom to decide what should be done in a particular situation.

examples.sentence: I leave the decision to your discretion.

definition: The faculty or power of using one's will.

examples.sentence: She left the company of her own volition.

definition: Small or meager.

examples.sentence: She was paid a paltry sum for her hard work.

definition: Lacking in quantity or quality.

examples.sentence: He supplemented his meager income by working at night.

definition: Of little importance; trivial.

examples.sentence: They argued over petty grievances.

definition: Of little value or importance.

examples.sentence: Don't get angry over such trivial matters.

definition: Unimportant or trivial.

examples.sentence: It was a trifling matter that we easily ignored.

definition: Too small or unimportant to be worth consideration.

examples.sentence: The cost was insignificant compared to the benefits.

definition: Without moral principles; ignoble.

examples.sentence: His actions were motivated by base instincts.

definition: A secret political clique or faction.

examples.sentence: A cabal of dissidents plotted to overthrow the government.

definition: A large crowd of people, especially one that is disorderly and intent on causing trouble or violence.

examples.sentence: The angry mob marched towards the palace.

definition: A small group of people with shared interests or tastes, especially one that is exclusive of other people.

examples.sentence: A coterie of scientists met privately to discuss the findings.

definition: A small organized dissenting group within a larger one, especially in politics.

examples.sentence: The party split into rival factions.

definition: A small group of people, with shared interests or other features in common, who spend time together and do not readily allow others to join them.

examples.sentence: The popular kids formed a tight clique at school.

definition: A connection or series of connections linking two or more things.

examples.sentence: The nexus between industry and political power is strong.

definition: Willingness to secretly allow or be involved in wrongdoing, especially an immoral or illegal act.

examples.sentence: The crime was committed with the connivance of the security guards.

definition: The process or fact of isolating or being isolated.

examples.sentence: The patient was kept in isolation to prevent the spread of infection.

definition: Intended to prevent disease.

examples.sentence: Vaccines are prophylactic measures against diseases.

definition: Designed to keep something undesirable such as illness or harm from occurring.

examples.sentence: Preventive maintenance can save money in the long run.

definition: Carried out as a precaution; preventive.

examples.sentence: He took precautionary measures to secure his home.

definition: Care taken to avoid danger or mistakes.

examples.sentence: Proceed with caution when driving on icy roads.

definition: A medicine or treatment for a disease or injury.

examples.sentence: There is no known remedy for this disease.

definition: The action of putting someone or something at risk or in danger.

examples.sentence: Child endangerment is a serious crime.

definition: An agreement.

examples.sentence: The international covenant on human rights was signed by many nations.

definition: A formally concluded and ratified agreement between countries.

examples.sentence: The two countries signed a peace treaty.

definition: A formal agreement between individuals or parties.

examples.sentence: They made a pact to always stay friends.

definition: A union or association formed for mutual benefit, especially between countries or organizations.

examples.sentence: The two parties formed a strategic alliance.

definition: An agreement between enemies or opponents to stop fighting or arguing for a certain time.

examples.sentence: The rebels declared a temporary truce.

definition: The official procedure or system of rules governing affairs of state or diplomatic occasions.

examples.sentence: It is against protocol for the Prince to do that.

definition: Give or grant someone (power, status, or recognition). agreement or harmony.

examples.sentence: His views are in accord with public opinion.

definition: Having a red or flushed complexion; elaborately or excessively intricate or complicated.

examples.sentence: His writing style is too florid for my taste.

definition: Made in an intricate shape or decorated with complex patterns.

examples.sentence: The room was filled with ornate furniture.

definition: Extravagantly bright or showy, typically so as to be tasteless.

examples.sentence: She wore a gaudy costume to the party.

definition: Ostentatiously attractive or impressive.

examples.sentence: He drives a flashy sports car.

definition: Very vivid in color, especially so as to create an unpleasantly harsh or unnatural effect.

examples.sentence: The papers were full of lurid details of the murder.

definition: Relating to or denoting a style of European architecture, music, and art of the 17th and 18th centuries that followed mannerism and is characterized by ornate detail.

examples.sentence: The church is a masterpiece of Baroque architecture.

definition: Obtrusively bright and showy; lurid.

examples.sentence: The room was painted in garish colors.

definition: Furiously angry.

examples.sentence: He was livid when he found out the truth.

definition: Not adorned; plain.

examples.sentence: The walls were unadorned and white.

definition: Not clothed or covered.

examples.sentence: The cupboard was bare.

definition: Read (something), typically in a thorough or careful way.

examples.sentence: She perused the document carefully.

definition: Examine or inspect closely and thoroughly.

examples.sentence: The police scrutinized the evidence extensively.

definition: Physically explore or examine something with the hands or an instrument.

examples.sentence: Journalists probed into his private life.

definition: Accept and allow (behavior that is considered morally wrong or offensive) to continue.

examples.sentence: The college cannot condone any behavior that involves illicit drugs.

definition: Pay no attention to; ignore.

examples.sentence: Please disregard the previous email.

definition: Inflicting or intended as punishment.

examples.sentence: The US imposed punitive tariffs on imports.

definition: Relating to punishment of offenders under the legal system.

examples.sentence: The penal system needs reform.

definition: Punishment inflicted on someone as vengeance for a wrong or criminal act.

examples.sentence: He feared retribution from his enemies.

definition: Make an attack or assault in return for a similar attack.
hindiSynonyms: ईंट का जवाब पत्थर से देना

examples.sentence: The army retaliated with an air strike.

definition: The inescapable agent of someone's or something's downfall.

examples.sentence: Mathematics was his nemesis in school.

definition: Reprimand (someone) severely.

examples.sentence: He was castigated for his constant tardiness.

definition: Show or declare that (someone) is not guilty of wrongdoing.

examples.sentence: The article exculpated the mayor.

definition: Absolve (someone) from blame for a fault or wrongdoing.

examples.sentence: The report exonerated the crew from all blame.

definition: Denoting a sin that is not regarded as depriving the soul of divine grace. (of a fault or offense) slight and pardonable.

examples.sentence: A venial sin is easily forgiven.

definition: Showing or motivated by susceptibility to bribery.

examples.sentence: The judge was known to be venal and easily bribed.

definition: An official pardon for people who have been convicted of political offenses.

examples.sentence: The government declared an amnesty for political prisoners.

definition: Destroy utterly; wipe out.

examples.sentence: The city was obliterated by the bomb.

definition: Destroy utterly; obliterate.

examples.sentence: A simple bomb could annihilate them all.

definition: Destroy completely.

examples.sentence: Hitler wanted to exterminate the Jews.

definition: Root out and destroy completely.

examples.sentence: The use of torture must be extirpated.

definition: Cause severe and extensive damage to.

examples.sentence: The hurricane ravaged the southern coast.

definition: (of an animal or force of nature) fierce, violent, and uncontrolled.

examples.sentence: He was the victim of a savage attack.

definition: Destroy completely; put an end to.

examples.sentence: The government aims to eradicate poverty.

definition: Restore to life or consciousness.

examples.sentence: The doctors managed to revive him.

definition: Holding firmly to an opinion or a course of action.

examples.sentence: She was pertinacious in her demands.

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action.

examples.sentence: He can be very obstinate when he wants to be.

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.

examples.sentence: The president remained obdurate on the issue of tax cuts.

definition: Resolutely or dutifully firm and unwavering.

examples.sentence: She remained steadfast in her belief.

definition: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely.

examples.sentence: He is a tenacious opponent.

definition: Stupidly obstinate.

examples.sentence: I was too pigheaded to listen to reason.

definition: Resembling or likened to a mule in being stubborn.

examples.sentence: She adopted a mulish expression and refused to speak.

definition: Hard to control or deal with.

examples.sentence: The problem proved to be intractable.

definition: Oppressively constant; incessant.

examples.sentence: The sun was relentless.

definition: Impossible to stop or prevent.

examples.sentence: The inexorable rise of unemployment.

definition: Having or showing a stubborn and determined intention to do as one wants, regardless of the consequences.

examples.sentence: A willful child who refused to eat his vegetables.

definition: Self-willed and obstinate.

examples.sentence: He is young and headstrong.

definition: Cease developing; be stagnant or rigid.

examples.sentence: The government's ossified bureaucracy.

definition: Haughty and stubborn.

examples.sentence: The stiff-necked refusal of the union to negotiate.

definition: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline.

examples.sentence: A class of recalcitrant fifteen-year-olds.

definition: Not showing fear or hesitation in the face of danger or difficulty.

examples.sentence: He looked at her with an unflinching gaze.

definition: Ready to accept control or instruction; submissive.

examples.sentence: A cheap and docile workforce.

definition: Ready to conform to the authority or will of others; meekly obedient or passive.

examples.sentence: She was far from being a submissive woman.

definition: Easily bent; flexible.

examples.sentence: Quality leather is pliable and soft.

definition: Willing to please others; obliging; agreeable.

examples.sentence: There are too many complaisant physicians signing sick notes.

definition: (of a substance or object) giving way under pressure; not hard or rigid.

examples.sentence: He was a gentle, yielding man.

definition: Having or showing an excessive willingness to serve or please others.

examples.sentence: He had always maintained a servile attitude regarding the director.

definition: Prepared to obey others unquestioningly.

examples.sentence: She refused to be subservient to her husband.

definition: Complying or willing to comply with orders or requests; submissive to another's will.

examples.sentence: A docile and obedient dog.

definition: A punishment or fate that someone deserves.

examples.sentence: He got his comeuppance in the end.

definition: Huge.

examples.sentence: Ordering the new equipment was a mammoth task.

definition: Of, resembling, or characteristic of an elephant or elephants, especially in being large, clumsy, or awkward.

examples.sentence: She has an elephantine memory.

definition: A huge or monstrous creature.

examples.sentence: Shoppers are now more attracted to the discount behemoths.

definition: Of imposing height.

examples.sentence: The elegant square was shaded by lofty palms.

definition: Of very great size or extent; huge or enormous.

examples.sentence: A gigantic concrete tower.

definition: Remarkably or impressively great in extent, size, or degree.

examples.sentence: The stove consumed a prodigious amount of fuel.

definition: Huge; enormous.

examples.sentence: They have a humongous dog.

definition: Extremely large.

examples.sentence: A colossal amount of money.

definition: Of exceptional strength, size, or power.

examples.sentence: A titanic struggle between good and evil.

definition: Very great in amount, scale, or intensity.

examples.sentence: He has a tremendous amount of energy.

definition: Impressively beautiful, elaborate, or extravagant; striking.

examples.sentence: A magnificent view of the mountains.

definition: (of a state, quality, or emotion) very great or intense.

examples.sentence: Her speech had a profound effect on me.

definition: Great in importance, extent, or size.

examples.sentence: It was a monumental decision.

definition: Enormous.

examples.sentence: A gargantuan appetite.

definition: Large and heavy or solid.

examples.sentence: A massive heart attack.

definition: Having the ugly or frightening appearance of a monster.

examples.sentence: A monstrous tidal wave.

definition: A very large aquatic creature, especially a whale.

examples.sentence: The factory is a leviathan of industry.

definition: A thing that is much smaller than normal, especially a small replica or model.

examples.sentence: A miniature railway.

definition: Extremely or unusually small.

examples.sentence: A diminutive figure.

definition: Extremely small; tiny.

examples.sentence: A minuscule amount of food.

definition: A person, animal, or plant that is much smaller than more typical members of its type.

examples.sentence: A pygmy hippopotamus.

definition: (in folklore or fantasy literature) a member of a mythical race of short, stocky humanlike creatures who are generally skilled in mining and metalworking.

examples.sentence: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.

definition: A very small person or thing.

examples.sentence: A midget submarine.

definition: Trivial or very small.

examples.sentence: The problems seem lilliputian compared to the tragedy of war.

definition: A lack of compatibility or similarity between two or more facts.

examples.sentence: There is a discrepancy between the two accounts.

definition: The fact or quality of being different, divergent, or inconsistent.

examples.sentence: Her story is at variance with the facts.

definition: The fact or state of being inconsistent.

examples.sentence: The inconsistency of his argument was obvious.

definition: The state or condition of being equal, especially regarding status or pay.

examples.sentence: Women have fought for parity with men in the workplace.

definition: A great difference.

examples.sentence: Economic disparities between different regions.

definition: The unjust or prejudicial treatment of different categories of people or things.

examples.sentence: He was a victim of racial discrimination.

definition: Lack of agreement or consistency.

examples.sentence: The discordance between the two groups.

definition: Agreement or harmony; compatibility.

examples.sentence: The results show quite good congruence with recent studies.

definition: Agreement or harmony between people or groups.

examples.sentence: They lived in peace and concord.

definition: The combination of simultaneously sounded musical notes to produce chords and chord progressions having a pleasing effect.

examples.sentence: The two countries lived in perfect harmony.

definition: Simultaneous performance of action or utterance of speech.

examples.sentence: They sang in unison.

definition: Speaking or spoken incessantly and fluently.

examples.sentence: A voluble game-show host.

definition: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.

examples.sentence: A garrulous taxi driver.

definition: Readily engaging in informal talk.

examples.sentence: He was in a chatty mood.

definition: Excessively or annoyingly talkative.

examples.sentence: She was a gabby neighbor.

definition: Tending to talk a great deal; talkative.

examples.sentence: She was very loquacious and told us all the news.

definition: Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily.

examples.sentence: She was reticent about her past.

definition: (of a person) reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.

examples.sentence: A taciturn man who rarely spoke.

definition: With the lips firmly closed, especially as a sign of suppressed emotion or determination.

examples.sentence: He remained tight-lipped about the deal.

definition: A shy, reticent person.

examples.sentence: He is an introvert and prefers reading to partying.

definition: An outgoing, overtly expressive person.

examples.sentence: She is an extrovert who loves meeting new people.

definition: A person who has a balance of extrovert and introvert features in their personality.

examples.sentence: Most people are ambiverts, falling somewhere in the middle.

definition: Willing to talk and engage in activities with other people; friendly.

examples.sentence: He is a very sociable person.

definition: In exactly the same words as were used originally.

examples.sentence: I copied his notes verbatim.

definition: Brisk and cheerful readiness.

examples.sentence: She accepted the invitation with alacrity.

definition: Able to move quickly and easily.

examples.sentence: He is as agile as a monkey.

definition: Quick and light in movement or action; agile.

examples.sentence: With a deft motion of her nimble fingers.

definition: Happening quickly or promptly.

examples.sentence: A remarkably swift recovery.

definition: Swiftness of movement.

examples.sentence: He acted with great celerity.

definition: Done without delay; immediate.

examples.sentence: Prompt action is required.

definition: Done with speed and efficiency.

examples.sentence: An expeditious investigation.

definition: Lack of strictness or care; negligence.

examples.sentence: The laxness of the local authorities.

definition: The action of violating someone or something.

examples.sentence: A violation of human rights.

definition: The action or state of forcing or being forced to do something; constraint.

examples.sentence: There is no compulsion to attend.

definition: A limitation or restriction.

examples.sentence: Time constraints make it impossible to do everything.

definition: Threats, violence, constraints, or other action brought to bear on someone to do something against their will or better judgment.

examples.sentence: He signed the confession under duress.

definition: A movement or series of moves requiring skill and care.

examples.sentence: A complex maneuver to park the car.

definition: The action of manipulating something in a skillful manner.

examples.sentence: The manipulation of the stock market.

definition: A secret plan by a group to do something unlawful or harmful.

examples.sentence: A conspiracy to overthrow the government.

definition: A plan made in secret by a group of people to do something illegal or harmful.

examples.sentence: A plot to seize power.

definition: A cunning plan or action designed to turn a situation to one's own advantage.

examples.sentence: It was just a ploy to get more money.

definition: A plan or scheme, especially one used to outwit an opponent or achieve an end.

examples.sentence: His chess stratagem was brilliant.

definition: A trick or device intended to attract attention, publicity, or business.

examples.sentence: It is just a publicity gimmick.

definition: The fact or process of ending or being brought to an end.

examples.sentence: The cessation of hostilities.

definition: Lack of action where some is expected or appropriate.

examples.sentence: The government was accused of inaction.

definition: Throw or drop (something) from an aircraft or ship.

examples.sentence: They jettisoned the fuel to lighten the load.

definition: Force or throw (something) out, typically in a violent or sudden way.

examples.sentence: He was ejected from the club.

Get rid of someone or something as no longer useful or desirable.

examples.sentence: He discarded the old newspapers.

definition: Cease to support or look after (someone); desert.

examples.sentence: The captain gave the order to abandon ship.

definition: To lose, drop, or get rid of something.

examples.sentence: The snake sheds its skin periodically.

definition: Manage without or get rid of.

examples.sentence: They decided to dispense with the formalities.

definition: Continue to have something; keep possession of.

examples.sentence: He managed to retain his dignity despite the insults.

definition: A difficult or unpleasant situation.

examples.sentence: She overcame many adversities to become a doctor.

definition: One's opponent in a contest, conflict, or dispute.

examples.sentence: He defeated his old adversary in the tennis match.

definition: Gather together or accumulate (a large amount or number of material or things) over a period of time.

examples.sentence: He amassed a fortune in the stock market.

definition: Gather together or acquire an increasing number or quantity of.

examples.sentence: Dust began to accumulate on the shelves.

definition: Gather or collect (something, especially information or approval).

examples.sentence: The movie garnered rave reviews from critics.

definition: Take in and understand fully (information or ideas); absorb and integrate.

examples.sentence: It takes time to assimilate new information.

definition: Assemble (troops), especially for inspection or in preparation for battle; collect or assemble.

examples.sentence: He mustered all his courage to speak.

definition: Accumulate or stack up.

examples.sentence: The work started to pile up while I was on vacation.

definition: A stock or store of money or valued objects, typically one that is secret or carefully guarded.

examples.sentence: Squirrels hoard nuts for the winter.

definition: (of sums of money or benefits) be received by someone in regular or increasing amounts over time.

examples.sentence: Interest will accrue on the account at a rate of 5%.

definition: Arrange or assemble (a group of people, especially soldiers) in order.

examples.sentence: The general marshaled his troops for battle.

definition: (of people) gather together in one place for a common purpose.

examples.sentence: A crowd assembled outside the courthouse.

definition: Gather into a crowd or mass.

examples.sentence: People began to congregate in the town square.

definition: Collect and combine (texts, information, or sets of figures) in proper order.

examples.sentence: The data was collated and analyzed.

definition: Unite; merge.

examples.sentence: Hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water.

definition: Waste time, money, or energy on trifling matters.

examples.sentence: He frittered away his inheritance on gambling.

definition: Throw in various random directions.

examples.sentence: The wind scattered the leaves across the lawn.

definition: Open out (something) so as to extend its surface area, width, or length.

examples.sentence: The fire spread rapidly through the forest.

definition: Distribute or spread over a wide area.

examples.sentence: Police used tear gas to disperse the crowd.

definition: To waste time.

examples.sentence: Don't fiddle away your time on useless things.

definition: Protection of or authority over someone or something; guardianship.

examples.sentence: He learned the trade under the tutelage of his father.

definition: The position of protecting or defending something.

examples.sentence: The child was placed under the guardianship of her aunt.

definition: The support given by a patron.

examples.sentence: The arts survived due to royal patronage.

definition: The protective care or guardianship of someone or something.

examples.sentence: The suspect is in police custody.

definition: The provision of what is necessary for the health, welfare, maintenance, and protection of someone or something.

examples.sentence: She is in the care of a nurse.

definition: The office or function of a tutor.

examples.sentence: He took up a tutorship at the university.

definition: Care, supervision, or responsibility.

examples.sentence: The babysitter was in charge of the children.

definition: The protection, backing, or support of a particular person or organization.

examples.sentence: The project was developed under the aegis of the UN.

definition: (of a country or region) having the freedom to govern itself or control its own affairs.

examples.sentence: The university is an autonomous institution.

definition: A change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant.

examples.sentence: He has been through many vicissitudes of life.

definition: An irregular rising and falling in number or amount; a variation.

examples.sentence: There was a fluctuation in the temperature.

definition: The repeated occurrence of two things in turn.

examples.sentence: The alternation of day and night is natural.

definition: A slight change in position, direction, or tendency.

examples.sentence: There was a sudden shift in the wind direction.

definition: The state of being stable.

examples.sentence: Political stability is essential for economic growth.

definition: The quality of being resolutely or dutifully firm and unwavering.

examples.sentence: Her steadfastness in her beliefs was admirable.

definition: The quality of being faithful and dependable.

examples.sentence: He is admired for his constancy to his friends.

definition: Clear (someone) of blame or suspicion.

examples.sentence: New evidence emerged to vindicate him.

definition: Show or prove to be right or reasonable.

examples.sentence: Can you justify your decision to quit?

definition: Free (someone) from a criminal charge by a verdict of not guilty.

examples.sentence: The jury acquitted him of murder.

definition: Check or prove the validity or accuracy of (something).

examples.sentence: You need to validate your ticket before boarding.

definition: Make (guilt or an offense) seem less serious or more forgivable.

examples.sentence: Nothing can extenuate such behavior.

definition: Publicly recommend or support.

examples.sentence: He advocates for human rights.

definition: Declare one's public approval or support of.

examples.sentence: The celebrity endorsed the new product.

definition: Speak or write in favor of (an action or person); attempt to justify.

examples.sentence: She defended her thesis successfully.

definition: Call into question the integrity or validity of (a practice). Also, charge (a holder of public office) with misconduct.

examples.sentence: The opposition tried to impeach the president.

definition: Declare (someone) to be guilty of a criminal offense by the verdict of a jury or the decision of a judge in a court of law.

examples.sentence: He was convicted of robbery.

definition: Express complete disapproval of, typically in public; censure.

examples.sentence: The government condemned the terrorist attack.

definition: Skilled at gaining an advantage, especially deceitfully.

examples.sentence: The wily fox escaped the trap.

definition: Having or showing skill in achieving one's ends by deceit or evasion.

examples.sentence: He is as cunning as a fox.

definition: Clever at achieving one's aims by indirect or deceitful methods.

examples.sentence: He made a crafty move to win the game.

definition: Clever or skillful, typically in a crafty or cunning way.

examples.sentence: The artful dodger managed to steal the wallet.

definition: Having or revealing natural creative skill.

examples.sentence: She has an artistic eye for design.

definition: Without guile or deception; natural and simple.

examples.sentence: Her artless charm won everyone's heart.

definition: (of a task, problem, or situation) requiring care and skill because difficult or awkward.

examples.sentence: It was a tricky question to answer.

definition: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with harmful effects.

examples.sentence: Glaucoma is an insidious disease.

definition: Having or showing a cunning and deceitful nature.

examples.sentence: He gave a sly grin.

definition: Acting or done in a secret or dishonest way.

examples.sentence: They used underhand tactics to win the contract.

definition: Given to or involved in making secret and underhanded plans.

examples.sentence: The scheming villain plotted against the hero.

definition: Arousing one's curiosity or interest; fascinating.

examples.sentence: The book has an intriguing plot.

definition: Having or showing sharp powers of judgment.

examples.sentence: He is a shrewd businessman.

definition: Having or showing an ability to accurately assess situations or people and turn this to one's advantage.

examples.sentence: She made some astute investments.

definition: Relating to a fox or foxes; cunning or crafty.

examples.sentence: He had a vulpine smile.

definition: Furtive; sly.

examples.sentence: It was sneaky of him to read my diary.

definition: Having or showing shrewdness and good judgment, especially in money or business matters.

examples.sentence: Canny investors bought the stock early.

definition: (of a person or action) showing a lack of experience, wisdom, or judgment.

examples.sentence: He was naive to believe her lies.

definition: Easily persuaded to believe something; credulous.

examples.sentence: He is so gullible he believes everything he reads.

definition: Having or showing too great a readiness to believe things.

examples.sentence: Credulous people are often targets for scams.

definition: The consequences or aftereffects of a significant unpleasant event.

examples.sentence: The country is rebuilding in the aftermath of the war.

definition: A result or effect of an action or condition.

examples.sentence: He must face the consequences of his actions.

definition: A proposition that follows from (and is often appended to) one already proved.

examples.sentence: A corollary of the theorem was easily proven.

definition: A consequence of an action or event, especially when complex or unwelcome.

examples.sentence: The political ramifications of the decision are unclear.

definition: The action of one object coming forcibly into contact with another; marked effect or influence.

examples.sentence: The environmental impact of the project is significant.

definition: The adverse side effects or results of a situation.

examples.sentence: The political fallout from the scandal was severe.

definition: The final or eventual outcome or conclusion of a discussion, action, or series of events.

examples.sentence: The upshot of the meeting was that we need more money.

definition: An unintended consequence occurring some time after an event or action, especially an unwelcome one.

examples.sentence: His resignation will have serious repercussions.

definition: A strong and adverse reaction by a large number of people, especially to a social or political development.

examples.sentence: The government faced a backlash over the new tax.

definition: Prolongation of a sound; resonance. Also, a continuing effect.

examples.sentence: The reverberation of the explosion was felt miles away.

definition: Something that takes place after or as a result of an earlier event.

examples.sentence: The movie sequel was better than the original.

definition: The arrival of a notable person, thing, or event.

examples.sentence: The advent of the internet changed everything.

definition: Come near or nearer to (someone or something) in distance or time.

examples.sentence: Winter is approaching fast.

definition: The process of coming into view or becoming exposed after being concealed.

examples.sentence: The emergence of new leaders gave hope to the party.

definition: The first appearance of light in the sky before sunrise; the beginning of a phenomenon.

examples.sentence: We woke up at dawn to start our journey.

definition: The beginning of something, especially something unpleasant.

examples.sentence: The onset of winter brought heavy snow.

definition: The start or beginning of something.

examples.sentence: He made it clear from the outset that he wouldn't stay long.

definition: The establishment or starting point of an institution or activity.

examples.sentence: She has been with the company since its inception.

definition: The origin or mode of formation of something.

examples.sentence: The genesis of the idea occurred during a walk.

definition: Begin; start.

examples.sentence: The ceremony will commence at noon.

definition: Begin and seem likely to continue (of something unpleasant or unwelcome).

examples.sentence: Panic began to set in as the water rose.

definition: A mass departure of people, especially emigrants.

examples.sentence: There was a mass exodus from the city before the hurricane.

definition: The action of leaving, typically to start a journey.

examples.sentence: His sudden departure surprised everyone.

definition: Bring to an end.

examples.sentence: The contract was terminated early.

definition: In a state or period of inactivity or dormancy.

examples.sentence: The volcano has been quiescent for centuries.

definition: Affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic.

examples.sentence: He felt lethargic after the big meal.

definition: (of a person) avoiding work; lazy. Also, not active or in use.

examples.sentence: The machines stood idle during the strike.

definition: An image or representation of a god used as an object of worship.

examples.sentence: The pop star is an idol to millions of teenagers.

definition: Mentally or physically inactive; lethargic.

examples.sentence: The heat made the workers torpid.

definition: Having normal physical functions suspended or slowed down for a period of time; in or as if in a deep sleep.

examples.sentence: The volcano has been dormant for 500 years.

definition: Lacking energy or enthusiasm.

examples.sentence: She had a listless handshake.

definition: Lacking enthusiasm and determination; carelessly lazy.

examples.sentence: He has a lackadaisical attitude towards his studies.

definition: Displaying or having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed.

examples.sentence: They enjoyed a languid afternoon by the pool.

definition: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.

examples.sentence: The indolent employee was fired.

definition: A tendency to do nothing or to remain unchanged.

examples.sentence: Bureaucratic inertia delayed the project.

definition: Sleeping.

examples.sentence: The slumbering giant awoke.

definition: Accepting or allowing what happens or what others do, without active response or resistance.

examples.sentence: He played a passive role in the relationship.

definition: Of or in a state of deep unconsciousness for a prolonged or indefinite period.

examples.sentence: The accident left him comatose for weeks.

definition: Lying face upward. Also failing to act or protest as a result of moral weakness or indolence.

examples.sentence: He lay supine on the beach.

definition: Sleepy; drowsy.

examples.sentence: The heavy meal made him feel somnolent.

definition: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.

examples.sentence: The professor's lecture was soporific.

definition: Showing great care and perseverance.

examples.sentence: She was assiduous in her duties.

definition: Requiring or using great exertion.

examples.sentence: The hike was very strenuous.

definition: Involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.

examples.sentence: It was an arduous journey across the mountains.

definition: Having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work or duties.

examples.sentence: A diligent student always does their homework.

definition: (of an argument or case) clear, logical, and convincing.

examples.sentence: She presented a cogent argument for the policy change.

definition: Involving hard or tedious work.

examples.sentence: Farming in those days was toilsome work.

definition: Great care or trouble taken to accomplish something.

examples.sentence: She took great pains to dress well.

definition: (of a person or action) showing dedication and diligence.

examples.sentence: He watched her with sedulous care.

definition: (especially of a task, process, or journey) requiring considerable effort and time.

examples.sentence: Writing the book was a laborious process.

definition: Requiring great strength or effort.

examples.sentence: Moving the piano was a Herculean task.

definition: An urgent need or demand.

examples.sentence: The exigencies of war forced them to leave.

definition: Very small in size or amount.

examples.sentence: He managed to survive on an exiguous income.

definition: The presence of something only in small or insufficient quantities or amounts; scarcity.

examples.sentence: There is a paucity of information on the subject.

definition: Small or insufficient in quantity or amount.

examples.sentence: The evidence against him was scanty.

definition: Thinly dispersed or scattered.

examples.sentence: The population is sparse in the desert.

definition: Entirely lacking or free from.

examples.sentence: His voice was devoid of emotion.

definition: A large or excessive amount of (something).

examples.sentence: There is a plethora of books on the subject.

definition: In abundance.

examples.sentence: There were bargains galore at the sale.

definition: Unusually or disproportionately large; excessive.

examples.sentence: He spends an inordinate amount of time on games.

definition: An excessive amount of something.

examples.sentence: A surfeit of food made him feel sick.

definition: A countless or extremely great number.

examples.sentence: There are myriad stars in the sky.

definition: Indefinitely many; a lot of.

examples.sentence: I have told you umpteen times to clean your room.

definition: (especially of something unwelcome or unpleasant) flourishing or spreading unchecked.

examples.sentence: Corruption was rampant in the country.

definition: Form branches or offshoots; spread or branch out.

examples.sentence: The problem ramified into many complex issues.

definition: Ostentatiously rich and luxurious or lavish.

examples.sentence: They lived in an opulent mansion.

definition: Exuberantly plentiful; abundant.

examples.sentence: He offered profuse apologies for the mistake.

definition: Abundant in supply or quantity.

examples.sentence: She took copious notes during the lecture.

definition: A severe flood. Also, a great quantity of something arriving at the same time.

examples.sentence: We received a deluge of complaints.

definition: Impose a misleading belief upon (someone); deceive; fool.

examples.sentence: Don't let him delude you with false promises.

definition: (of countryside) green with grass or other rich vegetation.

examples.sentence: The hills were verdant after the rain.

definition: (of vegetation) growing luxuriantly.

examples.sentence: The valley was full of lush vegetation.

definition: Enjoy oneself in a luxurious way; take self-indulgent delight.

examples.sentence: She luxuriated in a warm bubble bath.

definition: (of clothing or drapery) loose and ample. Also, (of writing) very lengthy and full.

examples.sentence: He wrote voluminous notes on the subject.

definition: Behavior, speech, or writing that is artificial and designed to impress.

examples.sentence: His British accent is just an affectation.

definition: A gentle feeling of fondness or liking.

examples.sentence: She has deep affection for her parents.

definition: Stylishly luxurious and expensive.

examples.sentence: They went to a swanky restaurant for dinner.

definition: Display (something) ostentatiously, especially in order to provoke envy or admiration.

examples.sentence: She likes to flaunt her wealth.

definition: A thing that is not what it is purported to be.

examples.sentence: Their marriage was a sham.

definition: An attempt to make something that is not the case appear true.

examples.sentence: He made a pretense of being busy.

definition: The use of fallacious arguments, especially with the intention of deceiving.

examples.sentence: He used political sophistry to win the debate.

definition: Pretentious and vulgar display, especially of wealth and luxury, intended to impress or attract notice.

examples.sentence: The house was furnished without ostentation.

definition: Conformity to facts; accuracy.

examples.sentence: Officials questioned the veracity of his statement.

definition: (typically of a woman) pleasant to look at; attractive.

examples.sentence: She is a comely young woman.

definition: Physically beautiful (often used humorously).

examples.sentence: The movie star was described as pulchritudinous.

definition: Ugly or disgusting to look at.

examples.sentence: The monster had a hideous face.

definition: Causing great horror or fear; frightful or macabre.

examples.sentence: It was a ghastly crime scene.

definition: Excessive admiration or praise.

examples.sentence: The actor enjoyed the adulation of his fans.

definition: The action of making something poorer in quality by adding another substance, typically an inferior one.

examples.sentence: The adulteration of milk is a crime.

definition: Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree.

examples.sentence: The waiter was obsequious to the rich customers.

definition: Persuade (someone) gradually or by flattery to do something.

examples.sentence: She tried to coax the cat out of the tree.

definition: Obsequious behavior toward someone important in order to gain advantage.

examples.sentence: His promotion was due to sycophancy, not merit.

definition: Displaying exaggerated flattery or affection; obsequious.

examples.sentence: The fawning audience laughed at every joke.

definition: Coax (someone) with kind words or flattery.

examples.sentence: He tried to blandish her into accepting the offer.

definition: Employ endearments or flattery to persuade someone to do something or give one something.

examples.sentence: She wheedled some money out of her father.

definition: Behaving in an excessively obedient or servile way as a means of gaining favor.

examples.sentence: I hate his constant bootlicking of the boss.

definition: A person who behaves obsequiously to someone important.

examples.sentence: Nobody likes a toady.

definition: Bring oneself into favor with someone by flattering or trying to please them.

examples.sentence: He tried to ingratiate himself with the new manager.

definition: Scold or rebuke.

examples.sentence: She chided him for his bad manners.

definition: Scold or criticize (someone) angrily.

examples.sentence: The coach berated the players for their poor performance.

definition: An attack on the reputation or integrity of someone or something.

examples.sentence: He cast aspersions on her character.

definition: Find fault with (someone); scold.

examples.sentence: She upbraided him for being late.

definition: Address (someone) in such a way as to express disapproval or disappointment.

examples.sentence: Her eyes were full of reproach.

definition: Harsh criticism or censure.

examples.sentence: His actions brought opprobrium upon the family.

definition: Trouble or annoy (someone) with frequent or persistent requests or interruptions.

examples.sentence: The kids pestered him for ice cream.

definition: Make (someone) feel annoyed, frustrated, or worried, especially with trivial matters.

examples.sentence: The question seemed to vex him.

definition: Irritate or annoy (someone).

examples.sentence: Her comments really nettled him.

definition: Ask (someone) repeatedly and annoyingly for something; pester.

examples.sentence: She badgered her parents to buy her a car.

definition: Put in a very difficult situation. Also, lay siege to.

examples.sentence: The beleaguered prime minister faced calls to resign.

definition: Subject (someone) to hostility and ill-treatment, especially because of their race or political or religious beliefs.

examples.sentence: Minorities were persecuted by the regime.

definition: (of a comment, event, or fact) cause annoyance or resentment that persists.

examples.sentence: The insult continued to rankle him for days.

definition: An annoying person, especially one who provokes others into action by criticism.

examples.sentence: He is a political gadfly who challenges the mayor constantly.

definition: Tease. Also, the husks of corn or other seed separated by winnowing or threshing.

examples.sentence: The boys chaffed him about his new haircut.

definition: Ask someone earnestly or anxiously to do something.

examples.sentence: I entreat you to help me.

definition: Beg someone earnestly or desperately to do something.

examples.sentence: She implored him not to leave.

definition: Harass (someone) persistently for or to do something.

examples.sentence: He importuned the editor for a job.

definition: Ask (someone) urgently and fervently to do something; implore.

examples.sentence: I beseech you to show mercy.

definition: Ask or beg for something earnestly or humbly.

examples.sentence: They supplicated the king for pardon.

definition: Ask for or try to obtain (something) from someone.

examples.sentence: The charity is soliciting donations.

definition: Make a forcefully reproachful protest.

examples.sentence: He went to the manager to remonstrate against the new rules.

definition: (of part of the body) soft and hanging loosely or limply, especially so as to look or feel unpleasant.

examples.sentence: His muscles became flaccid after months of inactivity.

definition: Drained of energy or vitality.

examples.sentence: The hot sun enervated the hikers.

definition: Insubstantial and easily damaged.

examples.sentence: The evidence was too flimsy to convict him.

definition: Deprived of strength or power; debilitated.

examples.sentence: He was incapacitated by the accident.

definition: (of a person) weak and delicate.

examples.sentence: She looked old and frail.

definition: Trembling or tottering, typically because of old age.

examples.sentence: The doddering old man needed help crossing the street.

definition: Strong and healthy; vigorous.

examples.sentence: He is in robust health.

definition: (of a person, animal, or thing) able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.

examples.sentence: Children are often more resilient than adults.

definition: Practicing or affecting strict religious or moral behavior.

examples.sentence: His puritanical views made him unpopular.

definition: Strictly honorable or honest. Also, vertical or erect.

examples.sentence: He was an upright citizen.

definition: Anxious or angry in a tense and overly controlled way.

examples.sentence: Don't get so uptight about small things.

definition: Having or showing high moral standards.

examples.sentence: She led a virtuous life.

definition: Diligent, thorough, and extremely attentive to details. Also, concerned to avoid doing wrong.

examples.sentence: He was scrupulous in his business dealings.

definition: Having or showing no moral principles; not honest or fair.

examples.sentence: The unscrupulous salesman tricked the elderly couple.

definition: An inner feeling or voice viewed as acting as a guide to the rightness or wrongness of one's behavior.

examples.sentence: His conscience bothered him after he lied.

definition: A qualification to an expression of agreement or approval; a doubt.

examples.sentence: I have some reservations about the plan.

definition: A stupid person.

examples.sentence: Don't act like an imbecile.

definition: Extremely stupid or foolish.

examples.sentence: That was an asinine comment.

definition: Silly and pointless.

examples.sentence: He made a fatuous remark.

definition: A person who is slow at learning; a stupid person.

examples.sentence: He was the class dunce.

definition: A foolish or stupid person.

examples.sentence: Only a nincompoop would believe that.

definition: A foolish or gullible person (Likely meant 'Simpleton').

examples.sentence: He is a simplet who believes everything.

definition: An ignorant or stupid person.

examples.sentence: He is a complete ignoramus when it comes to technology.

definition: Annoyingly insensitive or slow to understand.

examples.sentence: Are you being deliberately obtuse?

definition: A stupid, uncultured, or clumsy person.

examples.sentence: Watch where you're going, you clumsy oaf!

definition: Lacking sensitivity, refinement, or intelligence.

examples.sentence: It was a crass remark to make.

definition: A stupid person.

examples.sentence: He's such a dolt, he forgot his own birthday.

definition: A stupid or foolish person.

examples.sentence: Use your brain, you numbskull!

definition: A stupid person.

examples.sentence: Listen to me, you blockhead!

definition: Having or showing a perceptive understanding or insight; shrewd. Also, (of a bad situation) severe.

examples.sentence: She has an acute mind.

definition: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions, typically in a particular domain.

examples.sentence: He has remarkable business acumen.

definition: Wise, or attempting to appear wise.

examples.sentence: The sapient old man gave good advice.

definition: Having the experience and knowledge necessary to deal with the potential difficulties or dangers of life in an urban environment.

examples.sentence: You need to be street-smart to survive here.

definition: A book or set of books giving information on many subjects or on many aspects of one subject.

examples.sentence: He is a walking encyclopedia of sports trivia.

definition: Not telling the truth; lying.

examples.sentence: That was a mendacious statement.

definition: Based on a mistaken belief.

examples.sentence: His argument was based on fallacious reasoning.

definition: Invent or concoct (something), typically with deceitful intent.

examples.sentence: He fabricated a story to explain his absence.

definition: Superficially plausible, but actually wrong.

examples.sentence: It was a specious argument.

definition: A dishonest or unprincipled man.

examples.sentence: He is a charming rogue.

definition: Sly or cunning intelligence.

examples.sentence: He used guile to get what he wanted.

definition: A person who pretends to be someone else in order to deceive others.

examples.sentence: The doctor turned out to be an imposter.

definition: The offense of willfully telling an untruth in a court after having taken an oath or affirmation.

examples.sentence: He was convicted of perjury.

definition: A person who dishonestly claims to have special knowledge and skill in some field, typically in medicine.

examples.sentence: Don't trust that quack with your health.

definition: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose.

examples.sentence: He resorted to chicanery to win the election.

definition: A person who deceives others, especially in order to trick them out of their money; a charlatan.

examples.sentence: The mountebank sold fake cures to the villagers.

definition: Exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.

examples.sentence: It was a quixotic attempt to change the world overnight.

definition: An experience involving the apparent perception of something not present.

examples.sentence: He was suffering from hallucinations.

definition: An imagined place or state of things in which everything is perfect.

examples.sentence: The idea of a utopia is unrealistic.

definition: (of a mythical animal) formed from parts of various animals. Also, hoped for but illusory or impossible to achieve.

examples.sentence: His plans for wealth were purely chimerical.

definition: Waste (something, especially money or time) in a reckless and foolish manner.

examples.sentence: He squandered his inheritance on gambling.

definition: Disappear or cause to disappear. Also, squander or fritter away (money, energy, or resources).

examples.sentence: The fog began to dissipate.

definition: Spread (something, especially information) widely.

examples.sentence: The internet allows us to disseminate information quickly.

definition: Relating or devoted to that which is not sacred or biblical; secular rather than religious. Also, to treat (something sacred) with irreverence.

examples.sentence: He used profane language in church.

definition: Make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better.

examples.sentence: Steps were taken to ameliorate the situation.

definition: Give new and improved form, structure, or appearance to.

examples.sentence: The company decided to revamp its image.

definition: Put (something) right; correct.

examples.sentence: Please rectify the error immediately.

definition: Sign or give formal consent to (a treaty, contract, or agreement), making it officially valid.

examples.sentence: The treaty was ratified by all countries.

definition: Take apart (a piece of machinery or equipment) in order to examine it and repair it if necessary.

examples.sentence: The engine needs a complete overhaul.

definition: Make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.

examples.sentence: The new law only exacerbated the problem.

definition: Self-confidence or assurance, especially when in a demanding situation.

examples.sentence: He handled the crisis with great aplomb.

definition: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.

examples.sentence: She accepted the bad news with equanimity.

definition: Composure or coolness, sometimes excessive, as shown in danger or under trying circumstances.

examples.sentence: He displayed remarkable sangfroid during the fire.

definition: (of a person) having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition.

examples.sentence: He is a phlegmatic character who rarely gets angry.

definition: Resulting in good; favorable or advantageous.

examples.sentence: Regular exercise is beneficial to health.

definition: A person who derives advantage from something, especially a trust, will, or life insurance policy.

examples.sentence: She is the sole beneficiary of his will.

definition: Health-giving; healthy. Also, (of a place) pleasant; not run-down.

examples.sentence: The mountain air is very salubrious.

definition: (especially with reference to something unwelcome or unpleasant) producing good effects; beneficial.

examples.sentence: The accident was a salutary lesson in road safety.

definition: Producing a great deal of profit.

examples.sentence: It was a lucrative business deal.

definition: (of a time) well-chosen or particularly favorable; appropriate.

examples.sentence: He arrived at an opportune moment.

definition: Not harmful or offensive.

examples.sentence: It was an innocuous remark.

definition: Conducive to or suggestive of good health and physical well-being.

examples.sentence: She cooks wholesome meals for her family.

definition: Harmful, poisonous, or very unpleasant.

examples.sentence: Noxious fumes filled the room.

definition: Tending to cause harm.

examples.sentence: Smoking is detrimental to your health.

definition: A cause of great distress or annoyance.

examples.sentence: Mosquitoes are the bane of my existence.

definition: Threatening harm; menacing.

examples.sentence: He gave me a baleful look.

definition: Having an extremely offensive smell.

examples.sentence: A noisome stench came from the sewer.

definition: Full of danger or risk.

examples.sentence: It was a perilous journey.

definition: Risky; dangerous.

examples.sentence: These chemicals are hazardous to health.

definition: Dangerous; perilous.

examples.sentence: It was a jeopardous undertaking.

definition: Suggesting the presence of danger; threatening.

examples.sentence: Dark clouds gathered in a menacing way.

definition: Sufficient to cause death.

examples.sentence: The snake's venom is lethal.

definition: Having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way.

examples.sentence: The pernicious effects of smoking are well known.

definition: Tending to obstruct or harm. Also, unfriendly; hostile.

examples.sentence: These policies are inimical to growth.

definition: Causing harm or damage.

examples.sentence: Pollution has a deleterious effect on the environment.

definition: Of or belonging to the time before the biblical Flood. Also, ridiculously old-fashioned.

examples.sentence: His ideas are antediluvian.

definition: Inhabiting or existing in a land from the earliest times or from before the arrival of colonists.

examples.sentence: We studied the aboriginal art of Australia.

definition: In its original condition; unspoiled. Also, clean and fresh as if new.

examples.sentence: The beach was in pristine condition.

definition: Of or resembling the earliest ages in the history of the world.

examples.sentence: The forest looked primeval.

definition: Very old or old-fashioned.

examples.sentence: The law is archaic and needs to be updated.

definition: No longer produced or used; out of date.

examples.sentence: Typewriters are now largely obsolete.

definition: Grayish white; old and trite.

examples.sentence: He told a hoary old joke.

definition: Of no value or importance.

examples.sentence: The observation was nugatory.

definition: Not able to produce children or young. Also, free from bacteria or other living microorganisms.

examples.sentence: The needle must be sterile.

definition: (of land or a climate) having little or no rain; too dry or barren to support vegetation.

examples.sentence: The desert is an arid region.

definition: Dried out with heat. Also, extremely thirsty.

examples.sentence: The land was parched by the drought.

definition: Not producing offspring or fruit; sterile.

examples.sentence: The soil was infecund and unsuitable for farming.

definition: Incapable of producing any useful result; pointless.

examples.sentence: It was a futile attempt to escape.

definition: Assertive of authority in an annoyingly domineering way, especially with regard to petty or trivial matters.

examples.sentence: An officious security guard stopped us.

definition: Conceitedly assertive and dogmatic in one's opinions.

examples.sentence: He is too opinionated to listen to others.

definition: Inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true.

examples.sentence: He is very dogmatic about his political views.

definition: Unpleasantly domineering; trying to control other people's behavior and attitudes.

examples.sentence: She has an overbearing mother.

definition: Using power or authority without considering the feelings of others.

examples.sentence: The manager's high-handed manner alienated the staff.

definition: (especially of a person's manner or actions) insisting on immediate attention or obedience.

examples.sentence: He spoke in a peremptory tone.

definition: (of a person) easy to control or influence.

examples.sentence: The children were tractable and well-behaved.

definition: Quiet, gentle, and easily imposed on; submissive.

examples.sentence: She was as meek as a lamb.

definition: Inclined to agree with others or obey rules, especially to an excessive degree.

examples.sentence: He was compliant with all the rules.

definition: (of a person or manner) feeling or appearing casually calm and relaxed.

examples.sentence: He was surprisingly nonchalant about winning the award.

definition: Having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned.

examples.sentence: He was indifferent to their suffering.

definition: Showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern.

examples.sentence: The students were apathetic about the upcoming election.

definition: A person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining.

examples.sentence: He remained stoic despite the bad news.

definition: (of a person) calm, dependable, and showing little emotion or animation.

examples.sentence: The stolid security guard refused to smile.

definition: Not feeling or showing emotion.

examples.sentence: She kept her face impassive during the interrogation.

definition: Showing little enthusiasm. Also, (of liquid) only moderately warm.

examples.sentence: The proposal received a lukewarm response.

definition: (of an action or gesture) carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection.

examples.sentence: He gave a perfunctory nod as he passed.

definition: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest.

examples.sentence: He enjoys reading esoteric philosophy books.

definition: Difficult to understand; obscure.

examples.sentence: The professor's lecture was too abstruse for the students.

definition: Unable to speak distinctly or express oneself clearly.

examples.sentence: He becomes inarticulate when he is angry.

definition: (of language) open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning.

examples.sentence: The ending of the movie was ambiguous.

definition: Having a meaning that is mysterious or obscure.

examples.sentence: She sent me a cryptic message.

definition: Open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous.

examples.sentence: His answer was equivocal, leaving us confused.

definition: In the form of a cloud or haze; hazy. Also, (of a concept or idea) unclear, vague, or ill-defined.

examples.sentence: He has a nebulous idea of what he wants to do.

definition: Able to be understood; comprehensible.

examples.sentence: His speech was barely intelligible.

definition: Of uncertain, indefinite, or unclear character or meaning.

examples.sentence: She gave a vague answer.

definition: Not discovered or known about; uncertain. Also, not clearly expressed or easily understood.

examples.sentence: The details of his life remain obscure.

definition: Swollen and distended or congested. Also, (of language or style) tediously pompous or bombastic.

examples.sentence: His writing style is turgid and boring.

definition: (of a liquid) cloudy, opaque, or thick with suspended matter.

examples.sentence: The river water was brown and turbid.

definition: Able to be understood; intelligible.

examples.sentence: The instructions were easily comprehensible.

definition: (of a liquid) free of anything that darkens; completely clear.

examples.sentence: She looked into his limpid blue eyes.

definition: Expressed clearly; easy to understand. Also, showing ability to think clearly.

examples.sentence: He gave a lucid explanation of the complex theory.

definition: Clearly expressed and easily understood; lucid.

examples.sentence: His perspicuous arguments convinced the jury.

definition: Translucently clear.

examples.sentence: The water in the mountain stream was pellucid.

definition: Stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion or doubt.

examples.sentence: I gave you explicit instructions not to touch anything.

definition: A person who has been taken prisoner or an animal that has been confined.

examples.sentence: The soldiers were held captive for months.

definition: The condition of being imprisoned or confined.

examples.sentence: Animals bred in captivity often cannot survive in the wild.

definition: Attract and hold the interest and attention of; charm.

examples.sentence: She was captivated by his story.

definition: The state of being a slave.

examples.sentence: They were kept in bondage for years.

definition: The state of being confined in prison; imprisonment.

examples.sentence: His incarceration lasted ten years.

definition: The action of confining, or the state of being confined.

examples.sentence: He was placed in solitary confinement.

definition: The state of being a serf or feudal laborer.

examples.sentence: The peasants lived in a state of serfdom.

definition: The act of seizing and holding legal custody of something.

examples.sentence: The impoundment of the vehicle was ordered by the court.

definition: The state of being confined as a prisoner, especially for political or military reasons.

examples.sentence: During the war, many citizens faced internment.

definition: A person seized or held as security for the fulfillment of a condition.

examples.sentence: The terrorists held him hostage for three days.

definition: Kept secret or done secretively, especially because illicit.

examples.sentence: They had a clandestine meeting in the park.

definition: Kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of.

examples.sentence: She took a surreptitious glance at her watch.

definition: Behaving, done, or made in a cautious and surreptitious manner, so as not to be seen or heard.

examples.sentence: The cat made a stealthy approach toward the bird.

definition: Not openly acknowledged or displayed.

examples.sentence: It was a covert military operation.

definition: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble.

examples.sentence: He cast a furtive look over his shoulder.

definition: Existing beyond what is obvious or admitted; intentionally hidden.

examples.sentence: She had an ulterior motive for helping him.

definition: The disguising of military personnel, equipment, and installations by painting or covering them to make them blend in with their surroundings.

examples.sentence: The soldiers used branches as camouflage.

definition: A piece of fine material worn by women to protect or conceal the face. Also, something that hides or obscures something.

examples.sentence: A thin veil of mist covered the valley.

definition: Be or remain hidden so as to wait in ambush for someone or something.

examples.sentence: Danger lurks around every corner.

definition: Done or shown openly; plainly or readily apparent, not secret or hidden.

examples.sentence: His overt hostility was shocking.

definition: Legitimate, honest, and open.

examples.sentence: The deal was completely aboveboard.

definition: Full of twists and turns. Also, excessively lengthy and complex.

examples.sentence: The path to success is often tortuous.

definition: Having many curves and turns.

examples.sentence: The river followed a sinuous course.

definition: Extremely small. Also, a unit of time.

examples.sentence: The diagram showed the minute details of the cell.

definition: The face of a building. Also, an outward appearance that is maintained to conceal a less pleasant reality.

examples.sentence: Behind his cheerful façade, he was very lonely.

definition: A thin decorative covering of fine wood applied to a coarser wood. Also, a superficial appearance or show.

examples.sentence: His politeness was just a veneer.

definition: A person's face, with reference to the form or proportions of the features.

examples.sentence: His visage was grim and determined.

definition: The outer surface or structure of something.

examples.sentence: The exterior of the house needs painting.

definition: The way that someone or something looks.

examples.sentence: She takes pride in her appearance.

definition: The outward appearance or apparent form of something, especially when the reality is different.

examples.sentence: She tried to maintain a semblance of order.

definition: Nearer the front, especially situated in the front of the body or nearer to the head.

examples.sentence: The anterior part of the brain is damaged.

definition: Further back in position; of or nearer the rear or hind end.

examples.sentence: The posterior legs of the insect are longer.

definition: (especially of a person) unfortunate.

examples.sentence: The hapless victims were caught in the crossfire.

definition: Having or marked by bad luck; unlucky.

examples.sentence: It was an unfortunate incident.

definition: Destined to fail or have bad luck.

examples.sentence: The ill-fated voyage ended in disaster.

definition: (of a person) wretchedly unhappy or uncomfortable.

examples.sentence: He felt miserable after the breakup.

definition: (of something bad) experienced or present to the maximum degree. Also, (of a person or their behavior) completely without pride or dignity.

examples.sentence: They lived in abject poverty.

definition: Characterized by, expressing, or causing sorrow or misery.

examples.sentence: She told a woeful tale of her misfortunes.

definition: (of a person) in a very unhappy or unfortunate state.

examples.sentence: I felt wretched about what I had done.

definition: Having special rights, advantages, or immunities.

examples.sentence: She comes from a privileged background.

definition: Favored by or involving good luck or fortune.

examples.sentence: We are fortunate to have such good friends.

definition: A situation in which no progress is possible, especially because of disagreement.

examples.sentence: Negotiations have reached an impasse.

definition: A situation, typically one involving opposing parties, in which no progress can be made.

examples.sentence: The talks ended in a deadlock.

definition: A situation or condition in which there is no movement or activity at all.

examples.sentence: Traffic came to a complete standstill.

definition: A situation in which further action or progress by opposing or competing parties seems impossible.

examples.sentence: The war settled into a bloody stalemate.

definition: Bring or come to an abrupt stop.

examples.sentence: The car screeched to a halt.

definition: A period of time when the proceedings of a parliament, committee, court of law, or other official body are temporarily suspended.

examples.sentence: The court is in recess for the weekend.

definition: A deadlock between two equally matched opponents in a dispute or conflict.

examples.sentence: The hostage situation ended in a tense stand-off.

definition: A sudden, dramatic, and important discovery or development.

examples.sentence: Scientists have made a major breakthrough in cancer research.

definition: Move forward or make progress, especially when circumstances make this slow or difficult.

examples.sentence: We are making little headway against the strong wind.

definition: Of vital importance; crucial.

examples.sentence: It is imperative that you see a doctor immediately.

definition: Required by law or rules; compulsory.

examples.sentence: Attendance at the meeting is mandatory.

definition: Required by law or a rule; obligatory.

examples.sentence: Education is compulsory until age 16.

definition: Required by a legal, moral, or other rule; compulsory.

examples.sentence: It is obligatory to wear a seatbelt.

definition: Necessary for (someone) as a duty or responsibility. Also, currently holding office.

examples.sentence: It is incumbent on us to take action.

definition: Made necessary by particular circumstances or regulations.

examples.sentence: She lacks the requisite experience for the job.

definition: Requiring immediate action or attention.

examples.sentence: There is an urgent need for food and water.

definition: Absolutely necessary.

examples.sentence: His help was indispensable to the project.

definition: Available to be chosen but not obligatory.

examples.sentence: Attendance at the workshop is optional.

definition: Available for use at the discretion of the user.

examples.sentence: You have a discretionary budget for the project.

definition: Done, given, or acting of one's own free will.

examples.sentence: The organization relies on voluntary contributions.

definition: Done on purpose; deliberate.

examples.sentence: It was an intentional attempt to hurt her.

definition: (of something regarded as unpleasant) continuing without pause or interruption.

examples.sentence: The incessant noise drove me crazy.

definition: Without a break in continuity.

examples.sentence: We had three days of uninterrupted sunshine.

definition: Forming an unbroken whole; without interruption.

examples.sentence: The brain needs a continuous supply of oxygen.

definition: Never ending or changing.

examples.sentence: He seems to be in a perpetual state of confusion.

definition: Lasting or existing forever; without end or beginning.

examples.sentence: She promised him eternal love.

definition: Having or appearing to have no end.

examples.sentence: It seemed like an unending journey.

definition: Endless (often used hyperbolically).

examples.sentence: The meeting seemed interminable.

definition: Occurring at irregular intervals or only in a few places; scattered or isolated.

examples.sentence: There were sporadic outbreaks of violence.

definition: Occurring at irregular intervals; not continuous or steady.

examples.sentence: We had intermittent rain all day.

definition: Occurring often or repeatedly.

examples.sentence: She suffers from recurrent headaches.

definition: Appearing or occurring at intervals.

examples.sentence: He makes periodic visits to the doctor.

definition: (of the weather) unpleasantly cold or wet.

examples.sentence: The game was postponed due to inclement weather.

definition: (of something bad or undesirable) very great; intense. Also, strict or harsh.

examples.sentence: He suffered severe head injuries.

definition: Unpleasantly rough or jarring to the senses. Also, cruel or severe.

examples.sentence: The punishment was too harsh.

definition: Definition pending...
